entranceFees.description: Admits private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants. Valid for 7 days. If a vehicle pass is purchased, no other pass is necessary.
entranceFees.title: Acadia Entrance Fee - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one or two passengers on a private, non-commercial motorcycle. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Acadia Entrance Fee - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car (bicyclist, hiker, pedestrian). Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Acadia Entrance Fee - Per Person

data.directionsInfo: From Boston take I-95 north to Augusta, Maine, then Route 3 east to Ellsworth, and on to Mount Desert Island. For an alternate route, continue on I-95 north to Bangor, Maine, then take Route 1A east to Ellsworth. In Ellsworth, take Route 3 to Mount Desert Island.

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 12 months from purchase date. This pass provides access to Acadia National Park only. This pass admits the pass holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Acadia Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo: Located on Mount Desert Island in Maine, Acadia experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 45-90F (7-30C). Fall temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C). Typically the first frost is in mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 73 inches (185 cm). Winter temperatures range from 14-35F (-10 - 2C). Spring temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C).
data.name: Acadia

operatingHours.description: In support of federal, state, and local efforts to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19), all park roads, facilities, restrooms, carriage roads, campgrounds, visitor centers and services are closed. Please call or email for park information.
operatingHours.name: All park roads, facilities and services closed to slow spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)

data.description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats, and a rich cultural heritage. At 3.5 million visits a year, it's one of the top 10 most-visited national parks in the United States. Visitors enjoy 27 miles of historic motor roads, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads.

images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

images.altText: A man peers into a telescope as the Milky Way lights up the night sky.
images.title: Starviewing
images.caption: With dark skies, Acadia is a fantastic place to come see the stars.

images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.
